ElementDescription: The NDAR Global Unique Identifier (GUID) for research subject
Subject ID how it's defined in lab/project
Date on which the interview/genetic test/sampling/imaging/biospecimen was completed. MM/DD/YYYY
Age in months at the time of the interview/test/sampling/imaging.
Notes: Age is rounded to chronological month. If the research participant is 15-days-old at time of interview, the appropriate value would be 0 months. If the participant is 16-days-old, the value would be 1 month.

ElementDescription: Sex of subject at birth
Notes: M = Male; F = Female; O=Other; NR = Not reported

ElementDescription: Timepoint/visit label
Notes: e.g., Baseline, 6-Month Follow Up, Year 2; Morning, At Bedtime

ElementDescription: Briefly describe the child's current sleep problems:
Frequency of sleep problems per week
Since the child was first placed in your home have their sleep problems:
Weekday Bed time:
Weekday time to fall asleep:
Weekday wake time:
Weekend Bed time:
Weekend time to fall asleep:
Weekend wake time:
Are bed and wake times usually consistent?
Are bed and wake times usually consistent? If no, by what range do they vary?
Have you ever sought advice, support or treatment for this child's sleep problems?
Have you ever sought advice, support or treatment for this child's sleep problems? If yes, describe
Previous treatment/interventions tried for this child's sleep problems:
Any current sleep medications or supplements?
Does your child demonstrate any of the following: snoring/gasping while asleep?
Does your child demonstrate any of the following: snoring/gasping while asleep? If yes, can you hear your child from one room away?
Does your child demonstrate any of the following: excessive tiredness during the day?
Does your child demonstrate any of the following: breathing through his/her mouth while he/she is asleep?
Does your child demonstrate any of the following: Dry mouth when he/she wakes up?
Does the child frequently wake up while sleeping or complain of not being able to sleep?
Does the child wake up with shortness of breath?
Does the child experience excessive perspiration during sleep?
Does the child move a lot in their sleep?
Is the child hyperactive or aggressive?
Does the child experience headaches in the morning?
Does the child wet the bed?
Does the child suffer from emphysema, chronic bronchitis, or nocturnal asthma?
Does the child sleep walk?
Does the child sleep walk? How many times a week?
Does it happen during the first few hours of the night?
Is the child confused when/if awakened?
Does he/she demonstrate nonsensical behaviors while sleepwalking?
Does the child not remember the event in the morning?
Is it difficult to wake the person up?
Does the child have night terrors?
Does the child have night terrors? How many times a week?
Does the child scream, looks frightened, kick, does not seem to communicate during these episodes?
Does it happen during the first few hours of the night?
Does trying to awake him/her increases the problem?
Does the child not remember anything in the morning?
Does he/she have vivid and scary dreams?
Does he/she have vivid and scary dreams? How many times a week?
Does he/she wake up from this dream and feel sad, angry, or anxious?
Is the child fully alert upon awakening, with little confusion or disorientation?
Is recall of dream immediate and clear?
Do the nightmares occur in the latter half of the sleep period?
Is it hard for the child to return to sleep after a nightmare?
Does your child wet his/her bed?
Does your child wet his/her bed? How many times a week?
Does he/she wet also during daytime when awake?
Does he/she wet also during daytime when awake? How many days a week?
Does your child complain of inability to fall asleep, frequent night wakings, or waking up too early?
Does he/she worry about his/her problems falling or staying asleep?
Is your child tired during the day?
If your child showed signs of insomnia, how many times a week?
Does he/she refuse or stall going to sleep when asked?
Does he/she have many ''curtain calls?'' (one more kiss, food, drink..)?
Does the child struggle sleeping independently?
Does the child wake during the night and struggle to get back to sleep?
Does the child's school or social life suffer from their sleepiness?
Has the sleep disturbance coincided with an identifiable stressor that is psychological, psychosocial, interpersonal, environmental, or physical in nature?
Is the child's sleep disturbance is better explained by another current sleep disorder, medical or neurological disorder, mental disorder, medication use?
Does he/she have repetitive, stereotypic movements of arm or leg during sleep (over and over)?
Does he/she have repetitive, stereotypic movements of arm or leg during sleep (over and over)? How often?
Does he/she complain of daytime fatigue or sleep disturbance?
Does the child wake from sleep often?
Is the child tired during the daytime?
Does he/she have funny feelings or pain in legs at night, especially at bed time?
Does he/she have funny feelings or pain in legs at night, especially at bed time? How often?
Are these worse when the child tries to sit still?
Are these feelings temporarily relieved by rubbing or movement?
Does he/she grind his/her teeth during sleep?
Does he/she grind his/her teeth during sleep? How often?
Is there abnormal wear of the teeth?
Is there jaw muscle discomfort or pain?
Does he/she complain of headaches?
Does the child suffer from ''sleep attacks'' at inappropriate times?
Is the child excessively sleepy during the day?
Does he/she/they ever wake up and are unable to move or speak?
Does he/she describe scary visual images upon waking up?
How do sleep attacks, sleepiness, sleep paralysis and/or visual images occur?
Does the child have normal alertness, cognitive functioning, and behavior between sleep attacks?
Does the child ever suffer from a sudden loss of muscle tone (e.g., drooping of muscle on one side of the body)?
Does the child ever suffer from a sudden loss of muscle tone (e.g., drooping of muscle on one side of the body)? If YES, is this triggered by strong emotions?
Does the child take frequent naps?
Has the child ever been diagnosed with epilepsy or suffered from non-epileptic seizures?
Does the child sleep more than most of the same-age peers?
Is he/she unable to fall asleep at a conventional bedtime because they are not sleepy?
Is the child unable to awaken at conventional wake time (e.g., for school)?
When allowed to go to sleep at a later clock time, can he/she/they fall asleep quickly?
Does the child suffer from daytime sleepiness?
Do they fall asleep in school or other settings?
Does the child's sleep disturbance cause impairment with their social life or school?
What is the child's preferred sleep schedule?
